episode.content: As the Black Lives Matter protests continue across the U.S., there is another group fighting racism. Mirroring the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the number of hate incidents against people of Asian descent has also increased, and slanderous rhetoric like "China Virus" and "Kung Flu" are stoking racial tensions. How can we combat this stigma, prejudice and racism? We asked Dr. Russell Jeung, founder of an online organization that keeps track of racial incidents in the U.S.
episode.description: An experienced anchor Del Irani has a cutting-edge dialogue. This time, Prof. Russel Jeung at San Francisco State University talks about Anti-Asian Racism in US in the time of Coronavirus.
episode.subtitle: Fighting Anti-Asian Racism: Russell Jeung / Professor of Asian American Studies, San Francisco State University
episode.title: DEEPER LOOK from New York

episode.content: This year, as countries continue to grapple with the pandemic, there are many discussions about whether or not it is the right time to return to school. In the U.S., images of high school hallways packed with students not wearing facemasks went viral on social media, and in some states, schools have been forced to shut down shortly after reopening. But on the flipside, many students and their families are already experiencing difficulties with online learning. So, is this the right time to reopen schools? We asked the director of education UNESCO, Dr. Borhene Chakroun who joins us from Paris, France.
episode.description: An experienced anchor Del Irani has a cutting-edge dialogue. This time, she talks with Dr. Borhene Chakroun, Director of the Division for Policies and Lifelong Learning Systems in UNESCO.
episode.subtitle: Is it the Right Time to Reopen Schools?: Borhene Chakroun / Director, Division for Policies and Lifelong Learning Systems, UNESCO
episode.title: DEEPER LOOK from New York

episode.content: From concert halls and theaters to clubs and restaurants, many venues shutdown under the pandemic, depriving musicians and fans of the magic live music brings. But despite the lockdown, world-famous cellist Yo-Yo Ma picked up his instrument and began to play, sharing music remotely from his home to the world. Soon #SongsOfComfort became viral, providing a platform for artists, professionals or amateurs to express themselves. We asked Yo-Yo how music can help comfort us in these challenging times.
episode.description: An experienced anchor Del Irani has a cutting-edge dialogue. A world-famous cellist Yo-Yo Ma performed live at home to share his creation online. We asked him how music can help people amid pandemic.
episode.subtitle: How Music Can Give Comfort During the Pandemic: Yo-Yo Ma / Cellist
episode.title: DEEPER LOOK from New York

episode.content: The US presidential election and the chaotic aftermath have shown how deeply divided the country has been. And it looks like it will take a long time to fill the ditch. Yo-Yo Ma was born in France and immigrated to the U.S. in his childhood. He has played for successive presidents and seen the transition in the country. Our host, Del Irani, asked Yo-Yo Ma how he sees America. How can he find hope in the U.S.? And what role music can play.
episode.description: An experienced anchor Del Irani has a cutting-edge dialogue. She asks Yo-Yo Ma, a world-famous cellist, how he sees America today which is deepley divided and how he can find hope with music.
episode.subtitle: How Has America Changed?: Yo-Yo Ma / Cellist
episode.title: DEEPER LOOK from New York

episode.content: 2020 has become a historic year for women. Senator Kamala Harris will be the first woman and person of color to serve as Vice President of the United States. Women also made significant gains in both the House and the Senate. Still, the number of women who will hold seats in Congress is only about 26%, far from equal representation. How can we enhance women's participation in politics? And why is it important? We asked Debbie Walsh, who has been helping women run for public office.
episode.description: An experienced anchor Del Irani has a cutting-edge dialogue. This time, Debbie Walsh, director of Center for American Women and Politics, talks how we can enhance women's participation in politics.
episode.subtitle: How Can Women's Political Participation Be Enhanced?: Debbie Walsh / Director, Center for American Women and Politics, Rutgers University
episode.title: DEEPER LOOK from New York

episode.content: The year 2020 could go down in history. As the pandemic spread and the economy screeched to a halt, in the U.S., glaring income inequality and persistent racial disparities came to light. Then followed the contentious presidential election, further highlighting deep-seated divides. So, was 2020 the worst year ever? What can we learn from it? For our last episode of the year, we asked the renowned author Walter Isaacson for his insights and what history, and its great figures can teach us.
episode.description: An experienced anchor Del Irani has a cutting-edge dialogue. This time, Walter Issacson, author, ex-chaiman and CEO of CNN, and ex-editor for TIME Magazine, talks about how he remembers the year 2020.
episode.subtitle: How Will 2020 Be Remembered?: Walter Isaacson / Author, Professor of American History and Values at Tulane University
episode.title: DEEPER LOOK from New York
